Human Oversight & Accountability.justification: Score = 0.5 because 2 source(s) (listed below) contain only high-level principle statements.

relevantSources.title: Supplier Requirements
relevantSources.summary: Compliance requirements mentioning AI for process improvements and accountability mechanisms
relevantSources.evaluation: Mentions accountability and oversight in the context of AI for supplier compliance, but lacks concrete details about formal human oversight processes.

relevantSources.title: Italian Legislative Decree 231/2001
relevantSources.summary: Code of Ethics establishing oversight and compliance frameworks
relevantSources.evaluation: Describes general oversight and accountability frameworks, but does not provide detailed or AI-specific human-in-the-loop mechanisms.

Human Oversight & Accountability.findings: Lear's supplier and compliance documentation references accountability and oversight in the context of AI-enabled process improvements and ethical compliance. However, these sources do not describe concrete human-in-the-loop procedures or formal AI oversight committees.

Privacy & Security.justification: Score = 0.5 because 2 source(s) (listed below) contain only high-level principle statements.

relevantSources.title: Lear to Enhance Automation and Artificial Intelligence Capabilities
relevantSources.summary: Announcement of WIP acquisition for AI-based computer vision capabilities in manufacturing
relevantSources.evaluation: Mentions AI-driven systems and maintaining data security protocols, but does not provide detailed information on privacy or security standards.

relevantSources.title: Lear Corporation to Acquire Xevo, a Leader in Connected Car
relevantSources.summary: Acquisition of Xevo for connected car software and data analytics
relevantSources.evaluation: References machine learning, data analytics, and mentions end-to-end encryption and GDPR compliance, but lacks detailed privacy or security implementation specifics.

Privacy & Security.findings: Lear's acquisition announcements reference AI-driven data security, encryption, and GDPR compliance in automotive and manufacturing contexts. However, the sources do not provide concrete details on privacy or security practices specific to AI systems.

relevantSources.summary: Board appointment with expertise in AI trends in automotive industry

summary.overallFindings: Lear Corporation demonstrates some high-level acknowledgment of responsible AI principles in supplier compliance, governance, and privacy/security, but lacks concrete, detailed, or pillar-specific public documentation. No evidence was found for transparency, fairness, explainability, or public commitments and audits. The company's public AI-related materials are primarily operational or strategic, rather than focused on responsible AI frameworks or practices.
